Failure to do so may result in      protocol failures. -->  <rfc number="2172"      category="info"> <front> <title abbrev="MAPOS">MAPOS Version 1 Assigned Numbers</title> <author initials="M." surname="Maruyama" fullname="Mitsuru Maruyama"> <organization>NTT Software Laboratories</organization> <address> <postal> <street>3-9-11</street> <street>Midori-cho</street> <street>Musashino-shi</street> <street>Tokyo-180</street> <country>Japan</country> </postal> <email>mitsuru@ntt-20.ecl.net</email> </address> </author> <author initials="K." surname="Murakami" fullname="Ken Murakami"> <organization>NTT Software Laboratories</organization> <address> <postal> <street>3-9-11</street> <street>Midori-cho</street> <street>Musashino-shi</street> <street>Tokyo-180</street> <country>Japan</country> </postal> <email>murakami@ntt-20.ecl.net</email> </address> </author> <date month="June" year="1997"/> <area>Internet</area> <keyword>SONET</keyword> <keyword>assigned numbers</keyword> <keyword>synchronous optical network</keyword> </front> <middle> <section title="Abstract"> <t>    This document describes the protocol parameters used in the Multiple    Access Over SONET/SDH (MAPOS) version 1. MAPOS is a link layer    protocol and provides multiple access capability over SONET/SDH    links. </t> </section> <!-- RFC original section: (1.) --> <section title="Introduction"> <t>    Multiple Access Protocol over SONET/SDH (MAPOS) <xref target="_XREF_1"/> is a high-speed    link-layer protocol that provides multiple access capability over    SONET(Synchronous Optical Network)/SDH(Synchronous Digital    Hierarchy)<xref target="_XREF_2"/><xref target="_XREF_3"/><xref target="_XREF_4"/><xref target="_XREF_5"/>. Its frame format is based on the HDLC-like    framing <xref target="_XREF_6"/> for PPP.  A component called "Frame Switch" <xref target="_XREF_1"/> allows    multiple nodes to be connected together in a star topology to form a    LAN. Using long haul SONET/SDH links, the nodes on such a "SONET-LAN"    can span over a wide geographical area. The Internet Protocol (IP)    <xref target="_XREF_7"/> datagrams are transmitted in MAPOS HDLC frames <xref target="_XREF_8"/>. </t> <t>    This document describes the protocol parameters used in MAPOS version    1 <xref target="_XREF_1"/>. </t> </section> <!-- RFC original section: (2.) --> <section title="Protocol Field Assignments"> <t>    The MAPOS Version 1 Data Link Layer <xref target="_XREF_1"/> contains a 16 bit Protocol    field to identify the the encapsulated protocol.  The Protocol field    is consistent with the ISO 3309 (HDLC) extension mechanism for    address fields.  All protocol numbers MUST be assigned such that the    least significant bit of the most significant octet equals "0", and    the least significant bit of the least significant octet equals "1". </t> <t>    Assigned MAPOS Protocol Numbers <list> <t>       Value (in hex)  Protocol Name <list> <t>       0001-001F       Not Used - reserved </t> <t>       0021            MAPOS Version 1 Internet Protocol Version 4 <xref target="_XREF_8"/> </t> <t>       0023-FCFF       Not Used - reserved </t> <t>       FE01            MAPOS Version 1 Address Resolution Protocol (ARP<xref target="_XREF_8"/>) </t> <t>       FE03            MAPOS Version 1 Node Switch Protocol (NSP<xref target="_XREF_9"/>) </t> <t>       FE05            MAPOS Version 1 Switch Switch Protocol (SSP<xref target="_XREF_10"/>) </t> <t>       FE07-FEFF       Not Used - reserved </t></list> </t></list> </t> </section> <section title="Acknowledgements"> <t>    The authors would like to acknowledge the contributions and    thoughtful suggestions of John P.
